articles.headline: Sunak Announces U.K. Elections for July 4, Months Earlier Than Expected
articles.snippet: The opposition Labour Party has been ahead in most polls by double digits in recent months.
articles.abstract: The opposition Labour Party has been ahead in most polls by double digits in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain on Wednesday called a snap general election for July 4, throwing the fate of his embattled Conservative Party to a restless British public that appears eager for change after 14 years of Conservative government.

articles.headline: Nvidia, Powered by A.I. Boom, Reports Soaring Revenue and Profits
articles.snippet: The Silicon Valley company was again lifted by sales of its artificial intelligence chips, but it faces growing competition and heightened expectations.
articles.abstract: The Silicon Valley company was again lifted by sales of its artificial intelligence chips, but it faces growing competition and heightened expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nvidia, which makes microchips that power most artificial intelligence applications, began an extraordinary run a year ago.

articles.headline: Another Provocative Flag Was Flown at Another Alito Home
articles.snippet: The justice’s beach house displayed an “Appeal to Heaven” flag, a symbol carried on Jan. 6 and associated with a push for a more Christian-minded government.
articles.abstract: The justice’s beach house displayed an “Appeal to Heaven” flag, a symbol carried on Jan. 6 and associated with a push for a more Christian-minded government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, two years after an upside-down American flag was flown outside the Virginia home of Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., another provocative symbol was displayed at his vacation house in New Jersey, according to interviews and photographs.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor, Aric Toler and Julie Tate

articles.headline: Spain, Norway and Ireland Recognize Palestinian State, Further Isolating Israel
articles.snippet: The moves, while largely symbolic, were welcomed by Palestinians and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who called them “a prize for terrorism.”
articles.abstract: The moves, while largely symbolic, were welcomed by Palestinians and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who called them “a prize for terrorism.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Spain, Norway and Ireland said on Wednesday that they would recognize an independent Palestinian state, delivering a diplomatic blow to Israel that showed the country’s growing isolation on the world stage more than seven months into its devastating military offensive in the Gaza Strip.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman, Emma Bubola and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Almost 6,000 Dead in 6 Years: How Baltimore Became the U.S. Overdose Capital
articles.snippet: The city was once hailed for its response to addiction. But as fentanyl flooded the streets and officials shifted priorities, deaths hit unprecedented heights.
articles.abstract: The city was once hailed for its response to addiction. But as fentanyl flooded the streets and officials shifted priorities, deaths hit unprecedented heights.
articles.lead_paragraph: People in Baltimore have been dying of overdoses at a rate never before seen in a major American city.
articles.byline: By Alissa Zhu, Nick Thieme and Jessica Gallagher

articles.headline: The Increasing Trumpification of TikTok
articles.snippet: An internal analysis found nearly twice as many pro-Trump posts as pro-Biden ones on TikTok since November, a sign of the right’s use of a liberal-friendly platform.
articles.abstract: An internal analysis found nearly twice as many pro-Trump posts as pro-Biden ones on TikTok since November, a sign of the right’s use of a liberal-friendly platform.

articles.headline: Some of Silicon Valley’s Most Prominent Investors Are Turning Against Biden
articles.snippet: Marc Andreessen, Chamath Palihapitiya and several other tech venture capitalists are increasingly criticizing President Biden and making their disaffection known in an election year.
articles.abstract: Marc Andreessen, Chamath Palihapitiya and several other tech venture capitalists are increasingly criticizing President Biden and making their disaffection known in an election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2021, David Sacks, a prominent venture capital investor and podcast host, said former President Donald J. Trump’s behavior around the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol had disqualified him from being a future political candidate.

articles.headline: What Trump 2.0 Could Mean for the Federal Reserve
articles.snippet: A second Trump administration could shake up personnel and financial regulation at America’s central bank, people close to his campaign said.
articles.abstract: A second Trump administration could shake up personnel and financial regulation at America’s central bank, people close to his campaign said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump relentlessly criticized the Federal Reserve and Jerome H. Powell, its chair, during his time in office. As he competes with President Biden for a second presidential term, that history has many on Wall Street wondering: What would a Trump victory mean for America’s central bank?

articles.headline: A.I. Promised to Upend the 2024 Campaign. It Hasn’t Yet.
articles.snippet: With less than six months until the 2024 election, the political uses of A.I. are more theoretical than transformational. “This is the dog that didn’t bark,” said one adviser to a Democratic donor.
articles.abstract: With less than six months until the 2024 election, the political uses of A.I. are more theoretical than transformational. “This is the dog that didn’t bark,” said one adviser to a Democratic donor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence helped make turnout predictions in the Mississippi elections last year, when one group used the technology to transcribe, summarize and synthesize audio recordings of its door knockers’ interactions with voters into reports on what they were hearing in each county.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: In a City of Ancient Jewish Mysticism, Israelis Arm for a Fight
articles.snippet: In Safed, a center of kabbalah, ordinary citizens shocked by the Oct. 7 attacks are carrying military-grade weapons.
articles.abstract: In Safed, a center of kabbalah, ordinary citizens shocked by the Oct. 7 attacks are carrying military-grade weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eyal Ben-Ari tugged at the heavy assault rifle hanging over his shoulder as he tiptoed out of his pink house at sunrise, hoping not to wake his wife or six children.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Amit Elkayam

articles.headline: U.S. Calls for Breakup of Ticketmaster Owner
articles.snippet: Accused of violating antitrust laws, Live Nation Entertainment faces a fight that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live music industry.
articles.abstract: Accused of violating antitrust laws, Live Nation Entertainment faces a fight that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday sued Live Nation Entertainment, the concert giant that owns Ticketmaster, asking a court to break up the company over claims it illegally maintained a monopoly in the live entertainment industry.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Supreme Court Sides With Republicans Over South Carolina Voting Map
articles.snippet: The case concerned a constitutional puzzle: how to distinguish the roles of race and partisanship in drawing voting maps when Black voters overwhelmingly favor Democrats.
articles.abstract: The case concerned a constitutional puzzle: how to distinguish the roles of race and partisanship in drawing voting maps when Black voters overwhelmingly favor Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court cleared the way on Thursday for South Carolina to keep using a congressional map that a lower court had deemed an unconstitutional racial gerrymander that resulted in the “bleaching of African American voters” from a district.

articles.headline: Norfolk Southern to Pay $310 Million for East Palestine Accident
articles.snippet: The railroad company reached an agreement with the federal government to settle claims and costs from the 2023 derailment of a train carrying hazardous materials in the Ohio town.
articles.abstract: The railroad company reached an agreement with the federal government to settle claims and costs from the 2023 derailment of a train carrying hazardous materials in the Ohio town.
articles.lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern has agreed to pay more than $310 million to settle claims and cover costs stemming from the February 2023 derailment of a freight train carrying hazardous materials in an Ohio town, the federal government said on Thursday.
